question: Which climate would result in the fastest chemical weathering of rocks: warm and moist or cold and dry?

content.source_1: Chemical weathering rates increase with higher temperatures and abundant liquid water, because reactions such as hydrolysis and solution proceed faster under warm, wet conditions.
content.source_2: Equatorial tropical rainforests have year-round high temperatures, very high precipitation, and persistently moist soils and air.
content.source_3: In warm, wet tropical climates, chemical weathering of bedrock is intense; lateritic soils commonly form, and textbooks identify the tropics as the climate zone with the fastest chemical weathering.
content.source_4: The acidity of water strongly controls chemical weathering rates: carbonate minerals (e.g., calcite in limestone) dissolve far more rapidly at low pH than at neutral pH.
content.source_5: Acid deposition from industrial SO2/NOx or volcanic emissions can create chronically acidic rain and fog, causing very rapid dissolution and decay of limestone and marble surfaces even in temperate regions.
